content.title: Domaine de Bassilour, bespoke family stays

introduction.small: Located in Bidart, just three kilometres from Biarritz and a matter of steps from the Basque coast, the Domaine de Bassilour is home to three houses and 16 hectares of grounds.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Domaine de Bassilour, bespoke family stays

paragraphs.text:
Surrounded by sweeping, tree-filled grounds, the Domaine de Bassilour in Bidart is home to an eclectic mix of styles - from a Bourgeois mansion built in 1870, to a traditional Basque country farm, and spacious, modern villa with its own pool. For a stay full of character, choose the traditional 16th-century farmhouse, entirely renovated and offering elegantly spacious rooms with period furniture that are perfect for family holidays. You will feel right at home enjoying your morning coffee in the lush green garden, bathed in the Basque sunshine and smelling the sea spray on the ocean breeze.

For longer stays, why not play awhile at being lord and lady of the manor by staying in one of the manor house apartments, which can accommodate between two to five guests. Or, if you are planning a holiday with a big group of friends or a family reunion, then go for the estate's villa and private pool. With its seven rooms, space will definitely not be a problem! You could even enjoy a group cooking class with the chef during your stay, followed by a delicious gourmet dinner…

What is more, the Domaine de Bassilour not only does its utmost to ensure your wellbeing as guests, but also works hard to be as eco-friendly as possible: from using energy-saving bulbs and natural cleaning products to installing water savers in the bathrooms, geothermal heating and more. In fact, the hotel was the first in Aquitaine to be awarded the EU Ecolabel. Needless to say, you can look forward to a bespoke, sustainable stay, surrounded by nature and yet nice and close to some of the Basque Country's must-visit spots.

Domaine de Bassilour
1562 rue Bassilour
64210 Bidart

Tel : +33 (0)5 59 41 90 85

https://www.domainedebassilour.com/en/

Rooms: from 115 EUR

content.title: Hôtel du Palais, a legendary place full of history

introduction.small: A listed historic monument since 1993, this iconic hotel is the only imperial residence on the Atlantic coast and enjoys breath-taking ocean views.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Hôtel du Palais, a legendary place full of history

paragraphs.text:
Directly facing the ocean, the Hotel du Palais embodies the luxury and splendour of Biarritz: the 'Queen of beaches and the beach of kings'.

Formerly called 'Villa Eugénie', this palace hotel, built by Napoleon III for his wife, Eugénie de Montijo, is a historic monument where the dance steps of the great feasts given by the imperial couple still resound. Other prominent visitors have given their names to the hotel suites, with Ernest Hemingway, actress Romy Schneider, and Frank Sinatra among them.

The Second Empire decoration in the rooms has been lovingly preserved, calling to mind the pomp and refinement of that period by focusing on noble materials such as Carrara marble and Italian glass mosaic. Most rooms offer views of the Grande Plage, the majestic Biarritz lighthouse and the domes of the Orthodox church. The hotel is also home to fine dining restaurant La Rotonde. Seafood lovers will also appreciate Le Sunset and its sunny poolside terrace. The Guerlain Spa and the Leonor Greyl hair salon offer standout services.

Hôtel du Palais Biarritz
1 Avenue de l'Impératrice
64200 Biarritz

+33 (0)5 59 41 12 34

https://www.hyatt.com/en-US/hotel/france/hotel-du-palais-biarritz/biqub

Rooms: from 430 EUR

content.title: Chéri Bibi, ambassador of Basque gastronomy

introduction.small: In the heart of the Bibi Beaurivage neighbourhood facing the ocean, Fanny and François Lemarié cultivate Basque flavours in cans, on plates and even in bottles.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Chéri Bibi, ambassador of Basque gastronomy

paragraphs.text:
Located just a stone's throw from the Côte des Basques beach, Chéri Bibi offers fresh-produce and market-based cuisine. The menu changes according to deliveries and each day brings its share of news dishes. The Basque local products are turned into tapas to be shared and other typical specialities, such as the Judion beans (sort of navy beans) served with lemon peel, Basque breuil – a local fresh cheese – with Nardín anchovies and grilled peppers, and Kintoa sausage, made with a Basque species of pig.

A few other specialities are also available in can form, preserving flavours for the longest time possible: blood sausage, smoked anchovies, mackerels, sardines, Txogitxu Galician beef… And yet, the real pride and joy of Chéri Bibi remains its wine cellar: it offers natural selections as well as local other alcohols - try the Basque cider or the txakoli, a white wine made with green grapes, best enjoyed in moderation. At once bistro restaurant, wine cellar and cannery, the establishment exudes friendliness, carried by Fanny and François behind the vintage-looking yellow counter.

Chéri Bibi
50 rue d'Espagne
64200 Biarritz

+33 (0)5 59 41 24 75

https://www.facebook.com/cheribibibtz/

Menu: around 24 EUR

content.title: Enjoy specialities from the villages of Hondarrabia and San Sebastián

introduction.small: In the Spanish area of the region, tradition and good food combine to bring you Basque-style tapas, or “pintxos” as they are called here.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Enjoy specialities from the villages of Hondarrabia and San Sebastián

paragraphs.text:
First, head to Hondarrabia, a small fishing village on the Spanish border. For a more traditional excursion and a great family outing, take the boat in Hendaye which drops you off right at the port.

The walk through the small village's bustling streets to the old town will take you along the fortress wall, where you can enjoy stunning views of the entire bay. For either lunch or dinner, head to Rue San Pedro: a little jostling is required, but you will be well-rewarded with stewed chipirones, Bellota ham, and a glass of Rioja. This is also the place to go for the best pintxos in the entire Basque region: every bar and restaurant has its own speciality, often with its roots in a secret family recipe.

You will find the same party atmosphere in San Sebastián's casco viejo ("old town"). The best strategy is to visit in the afternoon: a stroll along the full length of the pier and a trip to the Museo de San Telmo are a must, as is a visit via cable car to the Monte Igueldo theme park and its unmissable panoramic viewpoint. If that makes you feel dizzy, the city aquarium will immerse you in the beauties of the underwater world instead. To end the day in style, hit the tapas bars.

content.title: Chez Albert, the must by the Port des Pêcheurs

introduction.small: Located on the dock of the Port des Pêcheurs (“Fisherman's port”), Chez Albert highlights Basque gastronomy using fish bought straight from the market in Saint-Jean-de-Luz.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Chez Albert, the must by the Port des Pêcheurs

paragraphs.text:
Ocean waves crash a few steps away from the kitchen at Chez Albert, where the staff pays tribute to the many products arising from the "Big Blue", according to Basque traditional skills. Plunged in the shade, the terrace faces the vastness of the sea, just like the deck of a ship reading to raise anchor. You too will dreamily gaze at the horizon, comfortably set on the port of the Basque city, only to lose the view in favour of flavourful dishes.

The restaurant has established itself as a reference and only serves wild catches for the freshest quality, sourced from local fishing. Seafood comes in various forms here, from classic platters (Gillardeau oysters, crab, prawns…) to grilled sardines from Saint-Jean-de-Luz, chipirones in cuttlefish ink sauce, paella and the must-try grilled lobster.

Proud of its local products, Chez Albert will take you on a trip around Basque traditions, complete from furniture to varied food specialities, with simplicity always at heart.

Chez Albert
51 bis allée du Port des Pêcheurs
64200 Biarritz

+33 (0)5 59 24 43 84

https://www.facebook.com/restaurantduportdespecheursbiarritz

Menu: around 40 EUR

content.title: High-end baroque stay at Beaumanoir

introduction.small: In a park only two kilometres away from Biarritz's Grande Plage, Beaumanoir stands out, looking like an Anglo-Norman summer cottage.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: High-end baroque stay at Beaumanoir

paragraphs.text:
Surrounded by giant lime trees, amid one hectare of greenery, Beaumanoir is a haven of peace only a few minutes from Biarritz's city centre. Set up in an ancient 19th-century manor and totally modernised, the hotel offers a five-star experience carefully thought out in every detail. The adventure begins the second you land at the airport, for a Rolls-Royce will pick you up and drive you to the premises, lined with olive, lemon and orange groves as well as vine stocks. Once you set up home in one of the eight suites displaying Neo-baroque tendencies, you can walk downstairs to the Bar Dom Pérignon to enjoy an exceptional glass of champagne from the 50 vintages on offer. After, you can choose to enjoy an outdoor massage, by the heated swimming corridor. If this is a family outing, the manor's nurse will gladly look after the kids, while the butler gives you a few tips on the best spots around. Local art of living in full!

Beaumanoir
10 avenue de Tamamès
64200 Biarritz

+33 (0)5 59 24 89 29

www.lebeaumanoir.com

Rooms: from 449 EUR

content.title: Le Pim'pi, bistronomic Basque cuisine

introduction.small: Only five minutes away from Biarritz's Grande Plage, Le Pim'pi offers authentic, bistro-style cuisine in which regional products are highlighted.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Le Pim'pi, bistronomic Basque cuisine

paragraphs.text:
Behind its bistro-looking red walls, in a small dining room with 30 seats, Le Pim'pi presents an unexpected take on food, far from clichés, an approach that has awarded it mentions in the Michelin guide since 2017. In a quiet street of the city centre, far from tourist circuits, the restaurant displays a bistronomic menu that keeps changing but always gives Basque products pride of place. With full transparency, Manu, the chef, even reveals his list of suppliers, all based in the region. As for Fanny, who is in charge of the wine cellar, she will introduce a selection of drinks from the South West that are certain to please hardened enthusiasts. A local Biarritz feel blows on the plates: what will it be? Zucchini cannelloni and trout from the Pyrenees, seared tail-on prawns, lemony pollock rillettes, hake tournedos with a herb, girolle and spring onion crust, red corn polenta, hake filet with eggplant rolls with ricotta, chorizo and artichokes… For dessert, take your pick between the vanilla rice pudding, crispy muscovado, mitchut pastis and pistachio ice cream. No fuss, the chef goes straight to the bone, showcasing simple and light, always refined cuisine.

Le Pim'pi
14 avenue de Verdun
64200 Biarritz

+33 (0)5 59 24 12 62

https://www.facebook.com/lepimpibistrot/

Menu: around 30 EUR

content.title: City of the Ocean: crack the secrets of underwater life

introduction.small: The seas take up three quarters of the earth's surface but they remain quite unfamiliar. The Cité de l'Océan (City of Ocean) answers all your questions through educational exhibitions.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: City of the Ocean: crack the secrets of underwater life

paragraphs.text:
Like a wave out of water, the Cité de l'Océan raises its structure only two steps away from the Milady beach. Conceived by New York and Brazil architects Steven Holl and Solange Fabião, the building perfectly blends with its surroundings, like an extension of the ocean on land. It falls within an eco-friendly approach with thermal self-regulation and rainwater collection.

If you have always been fascinated with the oceans, and the question as to whether Atlantis really existed keeps you up at night, then hasten to the Cité de l'Océan, where you can learn everything there is to know about these maritime topics. Various exhibitions recount the origins of the ecosystem, its importance in evolution and for human life, reveal the secrets of Atlantis or the Bermuda Triangle… and will also take you to meet the last common ancestor between men and whales.

Cité de l'Océan
1 avenue de la Plage
La Milady
64200 Biarritz

+33 (0)5 59 22 75 40

https://www.citedelocean.com/en/

content.title: Le Café de Paris, in the heart of Biarritz

introduction.small: Wake up to the sound of waves on the beach and gaze at the sunset, a drink in hand. There is no doubt about it, you're in Biarritz.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Le Café de Paris, in the heart of Biarritz

paragraphs.text:
Four-star Le Café de Paris Hotel shines on Biarritz's city centre. A stone's throw from the ocean, the lighthouse and the casino, it enjoys ideal location. The hotel's 19 bedrooms are all furnished in a contemporary style and the large French windows let natural light come in, while offering gorgeous views of the beach. "Beauty, luxury and endless ocean" is the hotel's sell: in the morning when you wake up, you will just have to open the window and enjoy the mild temperatures and the soothing sound of waves.

As the day ends, have dinner at the hotel's restaurant, where the chef prepares delicious seafood and local Basque dishes. Try the grilled sole in lemony butter or the calf's head with sauce gribiche. You can end the night just staring at the sunset from the bar's panoramic terrace.

Le Café de Paris Hotel
5 place Bellevue
64200 Biarritz

+33 (0)5 59 24 19 53

https://www.hotel-cafedeparis-biarritz.com/views/en/home.html

Rooms: from 137 EUR

content.title: Le Saphir Hotel, right in the heart of the city

introduction.small: The owners of this address impress with their sense of service.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Le Saphir Hotel, right in the heart of the city

paragraphs.text:
"We are a small hotel, close to our customers" summarise in unison the owners of this charming establishment in the centre of Biarritz. Close to the Vieux Port and 400m away from the Côte des Basques beach, Le Sapphire spreads over three floors with 15 pristine rooms. For such level of quality in the region, these affordable prices are hard to beat.

Closeness to the Basque coast allows for wonderful walks along the seafront or in the heart of the city (you will never feel the need to drive). Visit the Sainte-Eugénie Church, the Sea Museum, the Imperial Chapel, and dine at one of the many excellent restaurants nearby. Le Saphir is ideally located to enjoy the elegant seaside resort all year round, for a weekend – or longer if you don't want to leave!

Le Saphir hotel
3 rue Gaston Larre
64200 Biarritz

+33 (0)5 59 24 12 23

https://www.hotel-lesaphir.com/en/

Rooms: from 60 EUR

content.title: Hôtel du Palais

introduction.small: Legendary luxury hotel on the waterfront.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Hôtel du Palais

paragraphs.text:
Directly facing the ocean, the Hotel du Palais embodies the luxury and splendour of Biarritz the 'Queen of beaches and the beach of kings'.

Formerly called 'Villa Eugénie', this palace hotel, built by Napoleon III for the Empress, is a historic monument where the dance steps of the great feasts given by the imperial couple still resound. Other prominent visitors have given their names to the suites Ernest Hemingway, actress Romy Schneider, and Frank Sinatra among them.

The Second Empire decoration in the rooms has been lovingly preserved, calling to mind the pomp and refinement of that period by focusing on noble materials such as Carrara marble and Italian glass mosaic. Most rooms offer a peaceful view of the Grande Plage, the Biarritz lighthouse and the majestic domes of the Orthodox church. The hotel has a Michelin-starred restaurant 'La Villa Eugénie'. Seafood lovers will also appreciate the Hippocampe and its sunny terrace. The Guerlain Spa and the Leonor Greyl hair salon offer standout services.

Hôtel du Palais
1, Avenue de l'Impératrice
64200 Biarritz

+33 (0)5 59 41 64 00

www.hotel-du-palais.com

Rooms: from 349 EUR

content.title: Café du Commerce

introduction.small: The kind of place you wished you find more often in Biarritz.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Café du Commerce

paragraphs.text:
It looks like a brasserie that's been around for decades: oak floors, long counter, weathered walls, shelves filled with dishes, antiques, and good bottles of wine.

Take in the morning bustle of Les Halles with breakfast on the terrace. At lunchtime, the atmosphere becomes full-on brasserie: quick and efficient service, seafood platters, steak tartare, fish and chips, croque-monsieur, and smoked salmon bagels. Later in the day, aperitifs and snacks are available: charcuterie and seasonal cheeses, sardines from Spain, etc.

Café du Commerce
1, rue des Halles
64200 Biarritz

+33 (0)5 59 41 87 24

www.facebook.com/Café-du-Commerce-Biarritz-1383386805224657/

Menu: around 30 EUR

content.title: Surfing lessons on the Côte des Basques

introduction.small: The pro surfers of the École du Surf Français Biarritz give surf lessons to all levels.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Surfing lessons on the Côte des Basques

paragraphs.text:
The Côte des Basques is the most famous surf beach in France, attracting locals and surfers from around the world. Often described as a "French California", it is also great for windsurfing. The famous Villa Belza looks down on the beach, which only appears at low tide.

The striped tents of the surf schools on the Côte des Basques promenade offer surf lessons, supervised by professionals, for beginners and advanced surfers. A great opportunity to discover surfing codes and learn how to perfect your “take-off” position. Beginners will learn new sensations, which will be hard to suppress once you have had a taste of them.

Sessions invariably end with one of the most beautiful sunsets in the region, with the Spanish coast lying just off in the distance. If you are lucky, you just might get a glimpse of the famous "Green Ray", a rare meteorological phenomenon: a green spot becomes visible for a few seconds on top of the sun at the very moment it sinks into the horizon line.

École du Surf Français surf school
56 rue de Madrid
64200 Biarritz

+33 (0)5 59 41 11 18

https://www.ecole-du-surf-francais-biarritz.fr/about-us.html

content.title: Basque pelota

introduction.small: A traditional sport, where Basque villages play for glory.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Basque pelota

paragraphs.text:
Every village of the region, on the coast or inland, has its own fronton wall, on which pelota is played. The sport exists in different variants.

The cesta punta is among the best known, and probably the most impressive. It is practiced with a wicker glove: the chistera, which is still made, shaped and woven by hand by regional artisans.

The fronton often stands in the heart of the village, and everyone comes out to cheer on the new generations of players. The aitatxis "grandfathers" in Euskara keep score, often singing in Basque.

This traditional sport pits Basque village teams against each other, but also draws teams from Béarn, Soule, and throughout France. The greatest champions participate in world championships around the globe, from Miami to Mexico City.

For the curious, pelota demonstrations are offered on the fronton of Biarritz, close to the Mazon park. Initiations (beginners' session at 1:30 pm) and internships (3 to 5 days) for adults and children are organised at the Parcs des Sports Aguiléra by the Biarritz Athletic Club.

Biarritz Athletic Club (BAC)
Parc des sports Aguiléra
Rue Cino del Duca
64200 Biarritz
+33 (0)5 59 23 91 09
www.cesta-punta.com

Biarritztarrak
42 avenue Maréchal Foch
64200 Biarritz
+33 (0)9 65 17 45 38
https://bkpilota.besaba.com

content.title: L'Auberge Basque, preserved natural setting

introduction.small: Close to Biarritz and Saint-Jean-de-Luz, L'Auberge Basque welcomes you like an old friend, with an atmosphere conducive to letting go.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: L'Auberge Basque, preserved natural setting

paragraphs.text:
This traditional old building, formerly a family guest house, was modernised a few years back by the talented chef Cedric Béchade, who settled here after many years in the kitchens of Alain Ducasse at the Plaza Athénée in Paris.

The views of the mountains and the Rhune are spectacular. Inside and out, the decor subtly blends modernity and Basque tradition. It is a perfect showcase of contemporary Basque style: on the town side of the building, the façade is traditional, while large windows now provide panoramic views on the mountainside.

In the rooms, the floors are original, beds comfortable, colours soft, and showers ecological. The tailor-made breakfast menu is composed of Basque specialities made by local artisans. The gourmet restaurant also focuses on local and seasonal produce.

L'Auberge Basque
745 Vieille Route de Saint-Pée
64310 Saint-Pée-sur-Nivelle

+33 (0)5 59 51 70 00

https://www.aubergebasque.com

Rooms: from 170 EUR

content.title: Irresistible Basque pastries

introduction.small: At teatime, Biarritz abounds with popular gourmet spots.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Irresistible Basque pastries

paragraphs.text:
Established in Biarritz in the late 19th century, Miremont, with its easy-to-spot candy-pink storefront, remains a favourite stop for lovers of macaroons and homemade fudge. Among the treats on offer are the famous chocolate Béret Basque and the Paris Biarritz, choux pastry wonderfully adorned with local flavours: whipped chocolate cream, Itxassou cherry and Espelette pepper.

Do not pass up a chance to taste the spectacular Basque cake at Pariès, available in four flavours: almond cream, chocolate, black cherry, and hazelnut. The sweet delights continue at Thierry Bamas. Awarded Best Pastry and chocolate maker in France, he seduces locals and tourists alike with a selection of the world's best cocoas and irresistible creations like caramel truffle, Basque Coast "rocher" with almond praline and hazelnuts, and chocolate caviar. An ideal choice for a cocoa-suffused afternoon snack, to the delight of all children, and best enjoyed as a family outing after exploring the streets of Biarritz.

Miremont
1 bis place Clémenceau
64200 Biarritz
+33 (0)5 59 24 01 38
https://miremont-biarritz.fr/gb/

Pariès
1 place Bellevue
64200 Biarritz
+33 (0)5 59 22 07 52
https://paries.fr

Thierry Bamas
10 place Georges Clémenceau
64200 Biarritz
+33 (0)5 59 54 76 50
https://www.thierrybamas.fr

content.title: Hôtel de Silhouette, a fully-renovated heritage building

introduction.small: Just steps from Les Halles de Biarritz is the Hôtel de Silhouette, a well-kept secret oasis of tranquillity.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Hôtel de Silhouette, a fully-renovated heritage building

paragraphs.text:
In the heart of Biarritz's old town, not far at all from the Les Halles market, at the heart of local daily life and only a few metres from the sea, you will find a particular house, filled with a sense of history: the Hôtel de Silhouette. Entering the garden path to this gorgeous spot is the start of a journey of artistic discovery. The quaint architecture (built around 1600, making this one of the oldest buildings in the city) is juxtaposed with a totally eccentric mix of interior decoration: Italian wallpaper, pop colours, and antiques.

The 20 rooms offer 4-star hotel comforts. Some have balconies overlooking the hotel garden and the sea. There is no spa, but the hotel is partnered with the best spa centres in the region. As for the restaurant, it offers a classic bistro menu with fresh produce straight from Biarritz's Les Halles market.

Hôtel de Silhouette Biarritz
30 rue Gambetta
64200 Biarritz

+33 (0)5 59 24 93 82

https://www.hotel-silhouette-biarritz.com/en/

Rooms: from 149 EUR

content.title: Discover the Basque region

introduction.small: A journey of discovery through the history of the Basque Country, in the heart of its architectural and gastronomic heritage.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Discover the Basque region

paragraphs.text:
Make sure to put aside enough time for a drive out to Saint-Jean-Pied-de-Port, to discover what locals call "the heartland of Basque Country". Stop in front of one of the large traditional farmhouses of the region, which usually has a lauburu, the Basque cross, above the entrance door. These very singular white and red facade buildings, passed from generation to generation, are quaint hallmarks of Basque village life.

Among the most picturesque, Ainhoa is well worth a stop, with its unique street and typical, colourful architecture. 6 kilometres away, Espelette is a village known around the world for its pepper. Each year at the end of summer, the facades of the village houses are adorned with dozens of strings of peppers which, when dried and powdered, turn to "red gold". Close by, Itxassou is famous for its cherries and cherry jam. The specialty of the region, the Gateau Basque, is served with custard or jam, the choice is yours.

AaDT Béarn Pays basque
Petite Caserne
2 allée des Platanes
64100 Bayonne

+33 (0)5 59 30 01 30

https://www.biarritz-pays-basque.com/

content.title: La Ferme Ostalapia, at the foot of the Pyrenees

introduction.small: Not far from Biarritz, a place out of time with stunning views of the Rhune.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: La Ferme Ostalapia, at the foot of the Pyrenees

paragraphs.text:
Having a romantic dinner at the Ostalapia farm is a bit like privatising the Pyrenees just long enough for an intimate tête-à-tête. Located on an old route to Santiago di Compostela, the farm offers unobstructed views of both the Basque Mountains and the Rhune. Leave your jewels at home; tonight you are betting everything on authenticity. Come here to take your time and enjoy the small, simple pleasures of Basque cooking with fresh and seasonal products that make life better, like guinea fowl with cabbage, Banka trout with braised lettuce, octopus fideuà (a dish similar to paella made with vermicelli), roasted suckling pig with polenta, tuna steak with caramelised shallots and homemade fries, or perhaps a prawn and shellfish salad.
Finishing this romantic evening at the table of old friends sitting next to you is also known to happen, humming along to Basque songs while taking in the lovely scenery…

Ostalapia
2621 chemin d'Ostalapia
64210 Ahetze

+33 (0)5 59 54 73 79

https://www.ostalapia.fr

Menu: around 34 EUR

content.title: Crampotte 30, regional products and friendliness

introduction.small: A casual shack on the old port.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Crampotte 30, regional products and friendliness

paragraphs.text:
You do not know what a "crampotte" is? Under the reign of Napoleon III, heyday of Biarritz's fishing harbour, the crampotte in Gascon idiom described a "small house" where fishermen used to rest and store some equipment.

In the 1930s, one of these, the Crampotte 30, became a local landmark for its picturesque quality among boats and seagulls. It is easily recognisable by its green shutters and red tables.

Here a friendly spirit perpetually reigns among the regulars, who make coming here to share tapas, verrines and homemade preserves and delicacies a most inviting idea. Pâtés, meats, cheeses and other treats come directly from the market and from regional producers.

A relaxed atmosphere, it is the perfect place to kick back for a sundowner, a glass of txakoli in hand - please drink responsibly - as you set the world to rights and enjoy just being in the moment.

Crampotte 30
Port des Pêcheurs
64200 Biarritz

+33 (0)6 54 84 27 84

https://www.facebook.com/crampotte30/

Menu: around 15 EUR

content.title: Le Surfing restaurant, facing the ocean

introduction.small: The 'totally Californian' surfer's paradise on the Côte des Basques beach.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Le Surfing restaurant, facing the ocean

paragraphs.text:
The setting: the Basque coast and Biarritz's legendary waves. Surfboard in hand, staring at the ocean, you tuck into breakfast at Le Surfing.

A favourite for surfers, Le Surfing rides a new wave of Californian vintage. Surfboards cover the ceiling. Surf posters in bold retro colours cover the walls. All year round, the view of the waves and the sunrise from the beachfront terrace is astonishing.

Expect lunch and dinner menus, with platters to share (cold cuts, Basque cheese…), unless you would rather try the vegetarian poke bowl, featuring red cabbage, carrots, avocado, wakame and a rice vinegar dressing, or the Mister Surfing burger (cheddar, caramelised onions, mesclun salad, tomato confit and BBQ sauce). More classic fare includes salmon ceviche, sushi, fish and chips with tartar sauce, and low-temperature pork ribs with spicy honey sauce.

Le Surfing
9 boulevard du Prince de Galles
64200 Biarritz

+33 (0)5 59 24 78 72

https://www.lesurfing.fr

Menu: around 40 EUR

content.title: Les Halles de Biarritz

introduction.small: More than a simple market, Les Halles embodies a way of life dear to all locals.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Les Halles de Biarritz

paragraphs.text:
Completely renovated, Les Halles de Biarritz is a must visit for all epicureans.

Locals go there for an early breakfast before work during the week, and later in the morning on weekends. They shop, then meet up with friends for a drink, or to slurp back oysters at the L'Ecaillerie oyster bar, eat truffle omelettes at Maison Balme or Lebanese vine leaves at Mezze Ona, all accompanied by a freshly-squeezed juice on the terrace at L'Amuse Gueule.

A true temple of local gastronomy, Les Halles is full of delicacies and products of the region. Local cheese, fruit and seasonal vegetables are readily available, as is a myriad of Basque and Spanish charcuterie ham, chorizo, etc. plus freshly caught fish and - of course - the famous Gateau Basque.

At night, the whole Halles neighbourhood comes alive, as crowds pour into the area to kick off their evening.

Halles de Biarritz
Rue des Halles
64200 Biarritz

+33 (0)5 59 41 99 91

https://halles-biarritz.fr/en/

content.title: Le Madrid, for a drink… and more

introduction.small: Outside, inside, midday or midnight, in shorts or trousers, Le Madrid is a great place to spark up a conversation.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Le Madrid, for a drink… and more

paragraphs.text:
This is the headquarters of entrepreneurial, art-filled and creative Guéthary. Located in the central square of this small town, it is the perfect place to set up meetings from morning until evening on the terraces overlooking the sea and the town square. Once upon a time, sailors and railway workers used to gather in this then-wooden shack. In the 1930s, architect Albert Febvre-Longeray redesigned the café in Neo-Labourdin style, turning it into a restaurant-hotel.

The menu features coastal fish dishes, Ospital charcuterie platters and burgers. The atmosphere is hipster casual.

If you enjoyed the welcoming and friendly atmosphere, why not take advantage of one of the four rooms available? Located upstairs, they are decorated in 1950s Basque style, perfect for extending your stay, far from the crowds of Biarritz. The soul of the place has remained intact all those years, giving the café a unique and history-filled atmosphere where your mind can truly travel back in time.

Le Madrid
563 avenue du Général de Gaulle
64210 Guéthary

+33 (0)5 59 26 52 12

https://lemadrid.com/en/

Menu: around 35 EUR

Rooms: from 70 EUR

content.title: Chiberta's golf course, between the land and the sea

introduction.small: Considered to be one of the most beautiful golf courses in the region, Chibert'a golf course is situated between the pine wood and the seafront.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Chiberta's golf course, between the land and the sea

paragraphs.text:
Surfing is still the number one local sport, but the Basque Country is also a golfing destination, beloved by golfers the world over.

In spring and summer, it is best to book your tee time well in advance. On the road to Anglet, Chiberta is one of the region's exceptional golf clubs. Famous architect Tom Simpson designed the course. One of the provisions in his contract was to "build the world's most beautiful golf course". Furthermore, the sand bed from which it is made is the assurance you can play all year long, even after rainfalls.

There are two courses to choose from: 18 holes for seasoned players and Empress, a 9-hole course ideal for beginners and for upcoming talents to practice. The holes and fairways are a feast for the eyes: some, like the famous second hole, are on the seaside, while others are in a beautiful pinewood in the heart of the Chiberta forest. At the end of the day, enjoy a delightful walk along the coast, dividing the links and the beach.

Golf de Chiberta
104 boulevard des Plages
64600 Anglet

+33 (0)5 59 52 51 10

https://www.golfchiberta.com/accueil

content.title: The beaches of Anglet

introduction.small: Long overshadowed by their Biarritz counterparts, the beaches of Anglet are second to none with nearly five kilometres of fine sand.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The beaches of Anglet

paragraphs.text:
A favourite locale for surfers looking for big waves, the beaches of Anglet also have other sports activities on offer. Start the day off with a coastal walk or a morning swim. During the day, the infamously mythic "Petite Chambre d'Amour" ("Small House of Love", in reference to a local legend that took place in a nearby cave by the beach: Saubade and Laorens, two lovers in the 17th century, were surprised by the rising tide and swept away through the waves) becomes a vibrant place where life is good.

A pleasant lunch can be had, under the sun or shade, in a classic restaurant or as a takeaway snack. The Sables d'Or beach is lined with beach volleyball courts. La Barre has a skate park, skating rink and children's playground space. The many beach huts along the coast are the perfect place to stretch out a little later and catch the sunset.

Anglet Tourist Office
https://www.anglet-tourisme.com/en/do-see/sports-leisure/beaches/index.php

content.title: Partying at the Blue Cargo

introduction.small: Legendary hot spot on the beach of Ilbarritz with restaurant, beach, tapas bar, and dancefloor.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Partying at the Blue Cargo

paragraphs.text:
The trendiest place on the Basque coast attracts revellers from Bayonne to Saint-Jean-de-Luz. Its success is based on its unique beachfront restaurant concept that also offers an oceanfront dancefloor. Perfect for a couple or the whole family for lunch, and at night with friends to party.

On the menu, find local fare such as squid with Espelette pepper, '30-month' Bellota ham and tomato bread with garlic - a reminder that Spain is not far away -, whole louvine (seabass) for two, with olive oil or tomato sauce, or Ossau-Iraty cheese with black cherry jam from Itxassou.

Countless tapas are on hand during the cocktail hour, along with sushi and seafood. In the evening, after a dinner on the villa terrace facing the ocean, it is time to go down the small steps for a few moves and get up on the tables.

Open from April to October.

Blue Cargo
Ilbarritz beach
Avenue du Lac
64210 Bidart

+33 (0)5 59 23 54 87

https://www.bluecargo.fr

content.title: Enjoy specialities from the villages of Hondarrabia and San Sebastián

introduction.small: Tradition and gastronomy perfectly blend, for you to enjoy the culinary heritage of the region in skilful fashion.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Enjoy specialities from the villages of Hondarrabia and San Sebastián

paragraphs.text:
First, head to Hondarrabia, a small fishing village on the Spanish border. For a more traditional excursion and for a great family outing, take the boat in Hendaye which drops you off right at the port.

In the bustling streets of this small pueblo, the walk up the Historic district will take you along the fortress wall, from where you can enjoy unobstructed views over the entire bay. For either lunch or dinner, go to San Pedro: elbow your way in to small dishes of chipirones, Bellota ham, washed down with a glass of Rioja. They are the best pintxos in the entire Basque region and each institution has its speciality, often derived from secret family recipes.

In San Sebastián's casco viejo ("old neighbourhood") district, the atmosphere is also always festive. The best strategy: visit the old town in the afternoon, especially the full length of the pier and the Museo de San Telmo, as well as the Monte Igueldo theme park, accessible with a cable car, and the unmissable panoramic viewpoint. If you feel dizzy, the city aquarium will show you the beauties of the aquatic world. To end a perfect day, what could be better than hitting the tapas bars!

content.title: Climbing the Rhune Mountain

introduction.small: From the top you can enjoy a 360° view of the Pyrenees and the French and Spanish coasts.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Climbing the Rhune Mountain

paragraphs.text:
Less than an hour from Biarritz, the Rhune rises to 905 meters above sea level. For lovers of walks and hikes, it has many marked trails, suitable for all levels.

Depending on which trail you take, hikes to the summit take approximately 90 minutes to two hours.

Hiking trails hug the coast, allowing one to discover the coastline from a completely different perspective. Strange encounters are common: pottoks, the small, wild ponies of the Basque region, but also vultures and manech, the black-headed sheep of the region.

On the way back, stop at the Venta Yasola, a traditional Basque mountain inn, for plates of raw vegetables, omelettes, and patxaran liquor, all for about EUR 20.

Those feeling less athletic can get to the top by taking the little train from Sare. It climbs through the wilderness, offering glorious views along the way, and reaches the summit in 35 minutes.

La Rhune
64310 Ascain

+33 (0)5 59 54 20 26

https://www.rhune.com/en/
